snippet: While acknowledging shortfalls in response to Edward J. Snowden’s revelations, General Keith B. Alexander said the agency was doing more “to protect people’s civil liberties and privacy than they’ll ever know.”
abstract: Gen Keith B Alexander, National Security Agency director, asserts that collection of telephone and other electronic metadata from Americans is necessary to protect terrorist attacks; acknowledges that his agency faces new reality and possibility of Congressional restrictions after revelations about its operations at home and abroad.

byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER and THOM SHANKER

lead_paragraph: While acknowledging shortfalls in response to Edward J. Snowden’s revelations, General Keith B. Alexander said the agency was doing more “to protect people’s civil liberties and privacy than they’ll ever know.”

headline.main: N.S.A. Director Firmly Defends Surveillance Efforts
headline.print_headline: N.S.A. Director Firmly Defends Surveillance Efforts
